title: Warm-Up: Basic Structure

description.summary: Create a minimal HTML document that includes a title, a main heading, and a paragraph.

arguments.name: <!DOCTYPE>
arguments.desc: Defines the document as HTML5.

arguments.name: <html>
arguments.desc: Wraps the entire content of the HTML document.

arguments.name: <head>
arguments.desc: Contains information like <title> and meta tags.

arguments.name: <body>
arguments.desc: Holds all visible content such as headings and paragraphs.

arguments.name: ,
arguments.desc: Display a main heading and a short paragraph.

returns.desc: A valid minimal HTML document with basic structure and visible text.

examples:
Hello, world!

This is my first HTML document.

<html lang='en'>

solutionBlock.overview: This warm-up introduces the structure of an HTML document: doctype, head, and body. You’ll create a simple page with a title, one heading, and one paragraph.

title: Links and Images

description.summary: Create a clickable image link that is secure (target=_blank + rel) and accessible (non-empty alt). Note: in a sandboxed preview, opening a new tab may be blocked — tests focus on correct markup.

arguments.name: <a>
arguments.desc: Wraps content to make it clickable and navigates to another page or resource.

arguments.name: href
arguments.desc: Specifies the URL to navigate to when the link is clicked.

arguments.name: target="_blank"
arguments.desc: Opens the link in a new browser tab or window (may be blocked in sandboxed previews).

arguments.name: rel="noopener noreferrer"
arguments.desc: Prevents tab-napping and avoids giving the opened tab access to window.opener.
Displays an image; must include a non-empty alt attribute for accessibility.

returns.desc: A clickable image link with target='_blank', rel='noopener noreferrer', and a non-empty alt.

examples:
My Favorite Website

Click the image below to visit Wikipedia:

If this preview is sandboxed, the new tab may be blocked — that's expected.

web.starterHtml:
Clickable Image Practice

Your goal: make the image below link to another site.

Note: This embedded preview may block opening new tabs. Your code is still correct if the attributes are present.

solutionBlock.overview: Wrap the image in an <a> to make it clickable. Use target='_blank' plus rel='noopener noreferrer' for safe external links, and provide a non-empty alt for accessibility. In sandboxed previews, opening a new tab may be blocked — tests validate the markup instead of actual navigation.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Secure clickable image link
approaches.prose: The wraps the , making it clickable. target='_blank' opens a new tab in normal browsers, while rel='noopener noreferrer' prevents window.opener access and reduces tab-napping risk. The alt text stays non-empty for screen readers.
approaches.codeHtml:
My Favorite Website

Click the image below to visit Wikipedia:

If this preview is sandboxed, opening a new tab may be blocked. The markup is still correct.

pitfalls: Forgetting rel='noopener noreferrer' is a security risk when using target='_blank'.
Leaving alt empty makes the image inaccessible.
In sandboxed iframes, clicks may not open a new tab even when the markup is correct.
techniques: Wrap directly inside for a clickable image.
Always combine target='_blank' with rel='noopener noreferrer' for external links.
Validate structure and attributes instead of relying on real navigation in embedded previews.

title: Lists and Navigation

description.summary: Build a semantic navigation bar with internal links that show and hide corresponding content sections when clicked.

arguments.name: <nav>
arguments.desc: Defines a section of navigation links.

arguments.name: <ul>, <li>
arguments.desc: Used to create an unordered list for navigation links.

arguments.name: <a>
arguments.desc: Used inside list items to create clickable navigation links.

arguments.name: <section id='...'>
arguments.desc: Each section represents a page area (Home, About, Contact) that will be shown or hidden.

arguments.name: JavaScript logic
arguments.desc: Adds logic to hide and show sections dynamically based on the clicked link.

returns.desc: A semantic, accessible navigation bar that toggles visible sections without reloading the page.

examples:
• Home
  • About
  • Contact

Home

About

Contact

• Home
  • About
  • Contact

Starter content. Implement show/hide behavior so sections switch on click.

Starter content. This should appear when the About link is selected.

Starter content. This should appear when the Contact link is selected.

solutionBlock.overview: Use semantic HTML for structure and a small JavaScript script for interactivity. Each link updates the visible section and highlights the active link using `aria-current`.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Semantic navigation with show/hide behavior
approaches.prose: Use <nav> for navigation, <ul>/<li> for structure, and <section> for content. Add a small script that listens for hash changes and toggles visibility of matching sections while updating the active link state.

pitfalls: Without JavaScript, all sections will remain visible.
Forgetting to hide inactive sections makes the interface confusing.
techniques: Use <nav> for navigation semantics and <section> for content structure.
Use the hidden attribute to toggle visibility.
Use aria-current='page' to indicate the active link for accessibility.

arguments.name: <main>

arguments.name: <article>
arguments.desc: Encapsulates a self-contained composition like a blog post or article.

arguments.name: <section>
arguments.desc: Groups related content within the page or an article.

arguments.name: <footer>

Welcome to your semantic HTML layout exercise.

solutionBlock.overview: This exercise teaches semantic page layout. Instead of using generic <div> tags, use semantic HTML5 elements to structure your page — making it easier for screen readers and search engines to understand.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Semantic Blog Page
approaches.prose: Use <header> for the page’s introduction, <main> to contain your blog posts, <article> for individual posts, and <footer> for closing info. Inside each article, add a <section> for the main content to illustrate proper hierarchy.

title: Tables and Accessibility

description.summary: Create an accessible table listing employees with proper structure and semantics using <table>, <thead>, <tbody>, <th>, and <caption>.

arguments.name: <table>
arguments.desc: Defines a table for displaying tabular data.

arguments.name: <caption>
arguments.desc: Provides a concise description of the table’s contents for accessibility.

arguments.name: <thead> and <tbody>
arguments.desc: Separate the header row from the main table body.

arguments.name: <th>
arguments.desc: Defines column headers, typically placed inside <thead>.

arguments.name: scope="col"
arguments.desc: Specifies that a header cell applies to an entire column, improving screen reader navigation.

returns.desc: An accessible employee table with caption, headers, and rows, structured using semantic HTML.

examples:
Employee Directory
Name Role Email
Alice JohnsonDesigneralice@example.com
Bob SmithDeveloperbob@example.com
Carol LeeManagercarol@example.com

web.starterHtml:
Employee Directory

Below, build a semantic table with three employees and columns for name, role, and email.

solutionBlock.overview: Use semantic table markup to ensure both visual clarity and accessibility. The <caption> summarizes the table, <thead> groups header cells, and <th scope='col'> defines relationships for assistive technologies.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Accessible Employee Table
approaches.prose: Use <caption> to describe the data, <thead> for the column headers, and <tbody> for the content rows. Each header cell should have scope='col' to help screen readers associate data cells correctly.
approaches.codeHtml:
Employee Directory
Name Role Email
Alice JohnsonDesigneralice@example.com
Bob SmithDeveloperbob@example.com
Carol LeeManagercarol@example.com

pitfalls: Forgetting to add a <caption> makes the table less accessible to screen readers.
Leaving out scope attributes can confuse assistive technologies.
Avoid using tables for layout purposes — use them only for structured data.
techniques: Use <thead> and <tbody> to separate structure from content.
Always include <caption> for a clear summary.
Use scope='col' for column headers and scope='row' for row headers if present.

title: Forms: Input Basics

description.summary: Build a small form with labeled inputs for name and email, and a submit button. Each label should correctly associate with its input using matching 'for' and 'id' attributes. The form should look like a simple contact form that collects basic user information.

arguments.name: <form>
arguments.desc: Wraps interactive controls to collect and submit user input.

arguments.name: <label>
arguments.desc: Defines a text label for a specific input. The 'for' attribute must match the corresponding input's 'id'.

arguments.name: <input>
arguments.desc: Accepts user input; its behavior depends on the 'type' attribute such as text, email, or submit.

arguments.name: id and for
arguments.desc: The label's 'for' attribute must match the input's 'id' for proper accessibility.

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Defines the kind of input control (for example: text, email, or submit).

returns.desc: A functional and accessible form with two labeled input fields (name and email) and a submit button.

examples:
Example structure:
<form>
 <label for='name'>Name:</label>
 <input id='name' name='name' type='text' />

 <label for='email'>Email:</label>
 <input id='email' name='email' type='email' />

 <button type='submit'>Submit</button>
</form>

web.starterHtml:
Contact Form

Add labeled inputs for Name and Email. Make sure each label is correctly associated with its input using the 'for' and 'id' attributes.

solutionBlock.overview: This exercise introduces basic form elements and accessibility through labels. Using matching 'for' and 'id' attributes ensures that assistive technologies can correctly identify which label belongs to which input.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Basic Accessible Form
approaches.prose: Wrap inputs in a form element. Each input has a label with a 'for' attribute that matches its id. Use appropriate input types (text, email) and add a submit button to complete the form.
approaches.codeHtml: Form submitted!

pitfalls: Forgetting to connect labels with inputs makes forms harder to use for screen readers.
Using placeholder text instead of labels reduces accessibility.
Not setting input types correctly can cause wrong keyboards on mobile devices.
techniques: Always connect labels and inputs with matching 'for' and 'id'.
Use clear, descriptive labels to improve usability.
Wrap all related inputs in one form for submission.

webSolutionHtml: Form submitted!

title: Forms: Validation and Required Fields

description.summary: Add client-side validation to a signup form using built-in HTML5 attributes like 'required', 'pattern', 'type', and 'minlength'. The form should prevent submission when fields are left empty or invalid, displaying the browser’s default validation message.

arguments.name: required
arguments.desc: Ensures the user must fill out this field before submitting the form.

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Determines the input’s format, such as 'email' for email validation or 'password' for hidden characters.

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.desc: Defines a regular expression the input value must match (e.g., at least one number or uppercase letter).

arguments.name: minlength
arguments.desc: Specifies the minimum number of characters required for a text input.

arguments.name: validation feedback
arguments.desc: HTML5 automatically shows an error tooltip when invalid fields are submitted.

returns.desc: A functional signup form that prevents invalid submissions and provides built-in validation messages.

examples:
Example structure:
<form>
  <label for='name'>Name:</label>
  <input id='name' name='name' type='text' required />

  <label for='email'>Email:</label>
  <input id='email' name='email' type='email' required />

  <label for='password'>Password:</label>
  <input id='password' name='password' type='password' minlength='6' required />

  <button type='submit'>Sign Up</button>
</form>

web.starterHtml:
Signup Form

Add inputs for Name, Email, and Password. Use HTML5 validation attributes like required, type, and minlength so that invalid submissions show the browser's default validation message.

solutionBlock.overview: This exercise demonstrates how HTML5 validation works using built-in attributes like 'required', 'type', and 'minlength'. These attributes let the browser handle common validation without JavaScript.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Basic Signup Form with Validation
approaches.prose: Wrap your inputs in a form element. Use 'required' for all fields, 'type="email"' for email validation, and 'minlength' on the password field. When you try to submit invalid input, the browser will show its default validation messages automatically.
approaches.codeHtml: Form submitted successfully!

pitfalls: Omitting 'required' allows empty submissions.
Forgetting 'type="email"' disables built-in email validation.
Using 'pattern' incorrectly can block valid input if not tested carefully.
techniques: Always use 'required' on fields that must be filled out.
Use 'minlength' for passwords to enforce stronger inputs.
Combine HTML5 validation with JavaScript for more complex rules if needed.

webSolutionHtml: Form submitted successfully!

title: Forms: Grouping and Semantic Controls

description.summary: Build a short survey form that groups related controls using <fieldset> and <legend>. Include a gender section (radio buttons), an interests section (checkboxes), and a country dropdown using <select>. Each group should be labeled semantically to improve accessibility and organization.

arguments.name: <fieldset>
arguments.desc: Groups related form controls together for better organization and accessibility.

arguments.name: <legend>
arguments.desc: Provides a descriptive caption for the <fieldset>, helping screen readers identify the group.

arguments.name: radio inputs
arguments.desc: Allow selecting exactly one option within a named group.

arguments.name: checkbox inputs
arguments.desc: Allow selecting multiple options independently.

arguments.name: <select>
arguments.desc: Lets users choose one option from a list of countries.

returns.desc: A well-structured and accessible survey form with grouped radio and checkbox controls, and a country selector.

examples:
Example structure:
<form>
  <fieldset>
    <legend>Gender</legend>
    <label><input type='radio' name='gender' value='male' /> Male</label>
    <label><input type='radio' name='gender' value='female' /> Female</label>
  </fieldset>

  <fieldset>
    <legend>Interests</legend>
    <label><input type='checkbox' name='interests' value='coding' /> Coding</label>
    <label><input type='checkbox' name='interests' value='music' /> Music</label>
  </fieldset>

  <label for='country'>Country:</label>
  <select id='country' name='country'>
    <option value=''>Select...</option>
    <option value='turkey'>Turkey</option>
    <option value='usa'>USA</option>
    <option value='japan'>Japan</option>
  </select>

  <button type='submit'>Submit</button>
</form>

web.starterHtml:
User Survey

Group related form controls using <fieldset> and <legend> to improve organization and accessibility. Create radio buttons for gender, checkboxes for interests, and a <select> dropdown for country.

solutionBlock.overview: This exercise demonstrates how to semantically group related inputs using <fieldset> and <legend>. It also introduces radio, checkbox, and select controls for collecting different kinds of input.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Grouped Semantic Survey Form
approaches.prose: Use <fieldset> with <legend> to organize form sections. Create a radio group for gender, checkboxes for interests, and a <select> for country. These structures improve both screen reader accessibility and visual clarity.
approaches.codeHtml:
Gender
Interests

Survey submitted!

pitfalls: Not using <fieldset> makes it harder for screen readers to understand grouped inputs.
Forgetting to add <legend> removes contextual meaning for assistive users.
Using unrelated names for radio buttons prevents mutual exclusivity.
techniques: Always group related controls using <fieldset> and <legend>.
Use the same 'name' for radio buttons to ensure only one can be selected.
Label checkboxes individually for better accessibility.

Gender
Interests

title: Forms: Submission and Feedback

description.summary: Mark up a feedback form with a multiline text area, a submit button, and a confirmation area that announces updates using an ARIA live region set to 'polite'. Prevent page navigation and show 'Thank you for submitting!' after a valid submission.

arguments.name: <form>
arguments.desc: Wraps the feedback controls and handles submission.

arguments.name: <textarea>
arguments.desc: Collects multiline feedback. Use required and a sensible minlength.

arguments.name: <label>
arguments.desc: Associates text with the textarea via matching for and id.

arguments.name: submit button
arguments.desc: Use a button with type='submit' to trigger form submission.

arguments.name: ARIA live region
arguments.desc: An element with aria-live='polite' (optionally role='status') that announces confirmation text to assistive technologies.

returns.desc: A feedback form that prevents navigation on submit and updates a polite live region with a thank-you message when the input is valid.

examples: Example structure:

web.starterHtml:
Feedback

Create a form with a labeled textarea, a submit button, and a confirmation area that uses aria-live='polite' to announce updates.

solutionBlock.overview: Use a semantic form with a labeled textarea and a submit button. Add a confirmation element with aria-live='polite' (and role='status' for broader support). Intercept submit with JavaScript, validate via checkValidity/reportValidity, prevent navigation, and write the thank-you text into the live region.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Submit with ARIA Live Feedback
approaches.prose: The polite live region allows assistive tech to announce updates without interrupting the user. Using required and minlength on the textarea leverages built-in validation. Only after the form is valid do we show the thank-you message.

pitfalls: Forgetting aria-live on the confirmation area means screen readers may not announce updates.
Not preventing default navigation will reload or navigate the page on submit.
Placing the live region outside the form but not in the DOM flow can make it harder to find.
techniques: Use aria-live='polite' and role='status' for non-intrusive announcements.
Call reportValidity to show built-in messages before custom behavior.
Keep the live region present in the DOM (not created dynamically) so AT can monitor it.
